channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pressing Asia Agenda, Obama Treads Lightly on Human Rights
item.media:description: President Obama and his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping, in Hangzhou, China, on Saturday, on the sidelines of the G-20 summit.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by How Hwee Young
item.description: Some advocates fear the topic has fallen off the American list of priorities in the region amid Beijing’s rise as a geopolitical power.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Obama Takes a Detour to Reconnect With Southeast Asia
item.media:description: President Obama toured Wat Xieng Thong, a Buddhist monastery in Laos, on Wednesday.
item.description: The president spent time at a monastery and went shopping, but he also used a visit to a university to press for passage of the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Zimbabwe Follows Robert Mugabe’s Health by Following His Plane
item.media:description: President Robert Mugabe arriving home in Harare, Zimbabwe, on Saturday after a trip to the Middle East.
item.description: Government officials reveal little about the 92-year-old president’s condition or his travels, so Zimbabweans use apps to scour his flight path for clues.
item.dc:creator: HOPEWELL CHIN’ONO and NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Denmark Will Buy Leaked Panamanian Documents in Fight Against Tax Evasion
item.description: It was unclear if the files were from the so-called Panama Papers, but they originated with the same law firm at the center of an offshore finance scandal.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Camerawoman Who Kicked Refugees in Hungary Is Charged With ‘Breach of Peace’
item.description: Petra Laszlo was thought to have kicked a Syrian father who was holding his child, although prosecutors said her actions had not been motivated by bias or racism.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Turkish Official Says U.S. Was Not Complicit in Coup Plot
item.media:description: Deputy Prime Minister Numan Kurtulmus of Turkey in 2014. He said on Tuesday that Turkish leaders “don’t see any evidence that U.S. officials supported the coup d’état.”
item.description: In an interview on Tuesday with The New York Times Editorial Board, Turkey’s deputy prime minister said “we don’t see any evidence” of American involvement.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Iran and Saudi Arabia Squabble as Millions of Muslims Begin Pilgrimage
item.media:description: Pilgrims in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, on Tuesday. Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, called for the world’s Muslims to reconsider Saudi control of the holy sites.
item.description: The two nations traded barbs over which one best represents Islam and which one ought to control the religious sites at Mecca and Medina in Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Abroad in America: An Ugly Presidential Race Shows the World What It’s Missing
item.media:description: Controversies, mostly centered on Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, have dominated the news media this summer.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump enter the final nine weeks of a U.S. presidential campaign that has defied the expectations of both the American electorate and international observers.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Mexico’s Finance Minister Resigns After Trump Visit
item.media:description: Luis Videgaray
item.description: The minister, Luis Videgaray, is said to have come up with the idea of inviting Donald J. Trump to meet with President Enrique Peña Nieto.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Defense Secretary Warns Russia to Stay Out of U.S. Elections
item.media:description: Ashton B. Carter, the defense secretary, with President Obama in July. “The United States does not seek a cold, let alone a hot war, with Russia,” Mr. Carter said on Wednesday.
item.description: Ashton B. Carter harshly rebuked the Russian government, saying it wanted to “erode the international order.”
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Beijing Journal: China’s Tech-Savvy, Burned-Out and Spiritually Adrift, Turn to Buddhism
item.media:description: A view of Longquan Monastery, in the hinterlands of Beijing. In success-driven China, many people marvel at the decision of the temple’s monks to leave behind lucrative careers in the tech sector to devote themselves to Buddhist study.
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.description: The Longquan Monastery in northwest Beijing has become a haven for those seeking connectivity instead of seclusion, and practical advice rather than deep philosophy.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Doctors in Aleppo Tend to Scores of Victims in Gas Attack
item.description: More than 120 people were sickened in Aleppo. Separately, rebels in London described their vision for a political transition.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Some See Anti-Women Backlash in Ouster of Brazil’s President
item.media:description: Demonstrators protested the ouster of President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil last week in Rio de Janeiro.
item.description: Female politicians across Brazil are debating what the removal of Dilma Rousseff, the country’s first female president, means in a political realm dominated by men.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO and ANNA JEAN KAISER

item.title: The Interpreter: Obama, Acknowledging U.S. Misdeeds Abroad, Quietly Reframes American Power
item.media:description: President Obama on Tuesday at the Lao National Cultural Hall in Vientiane, Laos. Mr. Obama said the United States has a moral obligation to help Laos heal from the Vietnam War.
item.description: It has become practically routine for President Obama, in his final year in office, to acknowledge the United States’ unsavory history in a country he was visiting.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: After Edward Snowden Fled U.S., Asylum Seekers in Hong Kong Took Him In
item.media:description: News of Edward Snowden, a contractor for the United States National Security Agency who leaked top secret information, was broadcast on a Hong Kong train on June 14, 2013. Mr. Snowden was hiding in Hong Kong at the time before turning up in Moscow a little over a week later.
item.description: At least four people seeking refuge in the city have come forward to describe how they secretly hosted the former National Security Agency contractor in June 2013.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: W.H.O. Clarifies Advice on Sex and Pregnancy in Zika Regions
item.media:description: Condoms and literature on the prevention of the Zika virus and other diseases were handed out on Aug. 31 by health clinic workers in Loiza, Puerto Rico, to fight a spreading epidemic.
item.description: A spokeswoman said, “We want it to be unmistakable that we are not counseling anybody toward delay.”
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Mauricio Funes, Ex-Leader of El Salvador Under Inquiry, Gains Asylum
item.media:description: Mauricio Funes, the former president of El Salvador, in 2012.
item.description: Nicaragua granted asylum to Mr. Funes, who has been under investigation by the Salvadoran authorities for suspicion of corruption.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Bad Luck and Worse Manners Tarnish Obama’s Asia Trip
item.media:description: President Obama during a luncheon on Tuesday at the Presidential Palace in Vientiane, Laos, with President Bounnhang Vorachith, seated at left.
item.description: The trip brought progress, but it was marred by a chaotic arrival ceremony in China and an ugly personal outburst from the Philippine president.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Nearly 50 Million Children Are Refugees, Unicef Report Finds
item.media:description: A Syrian family at a refugee camp in Greece in August. The United Nations said on Monday that Syria and Afghanistan accounted for nearly half of all child refugees last year.
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.description: According to the agency, children make up a third of the world’s population but about half of all refugees.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Anjem Choudary Is Sentenced to Prison for Promoting ISIS
item.media:description: Anjem Choudary in January outside the Old Bailey in London. He was sentenced on Tuesday to five years and six months in prison.
item.description: Mr. Choudary, one of Britain’s best known Islamist activists, and an associate, Mohammed Mizanur Rahman, were both sentenced on Tuesday to five and a half years in prison.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Malaysian Rivals’ Reunion Highlights Shifting Political Alliances
item.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim, left, the jailed opposition leader, met with Malaysia’s former prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, right, at the High Court in Kuala Lumpur on Monday.
item.description: The court reunion of Anwar Ibrahim, who is imprisoned, and Mahathir Mohamad, the former prime minister who put him away, highlighted Malaysia’s fractious politics.
item.dc:creator: STÉPHANIE GIRY

item.title: New Karachi Mayor Gets Daytrip From Prison to Be Sworn In
item.media:description: Waseem Akhtar in an armored vehicle returning him to prison after he was sworn in as mayor of Karachi, Pakistan, last week.
item.description: The election of Waseem Akhtar to lead the city of 22 million comes as his Muttahida Qaumi Movement and its exiled leader are under fire from Pakistan’s military.
item.dc:creator: ZIA ur-REHMAN and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Letter From Europe: U.N. Chief Presses to Unlock Mystery of Dag Hammarskjold’s Death
item.media:description: The site of the plane crash that killed Dag Hammarskjold in a forest near Ndola, in what was then called Northern Rhodesia, now Zambia, in September 1961.
item.description: Britain and the United States have stonewalled requests by Ban Ki-moon to divulge information on the plane crash that killed his predecessor in 1961.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Tel Aviv Journal: Guerrilla Art Exhibit Unmasks the Face of Terrorism
item.media:description: The site of an attack in Tel Aviv on Jan. 1. On Monday, a guerrilla art exhibition projected scenes from the attack on giant screens over Dizengoff Square, near where the shootings took place.
item.description: Above Dizengoff Square, a killer’s face and hateful words are on display as part of an Israeli philanthropist’s mission to get his country to confront terrorism.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Keith Vaz, British Lawmaker, Quits Senior Post Amid Sex and Drug Scandal
item.media:description: The constituency office of Keith Vaz, a high-ranking Labour Party lawmaker, in Leicester, England, on Sunday.
item.description: The high-profile Labour politician resigned as head of a Home Office oversight committee after a tabloid reported he had met two men working as prostitutes.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Chinese Company’s Payment to Lawmaker Sets Off Furor in Australia
item.media:description: Senator Sam Dastyari of the Labor Party in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday. In the last week, he has faced intense pressure over a Chinese company’s donation of about $1,270.
item.description: Senator Sam Dastyari apologized for accepting the $1,270 donation, which has provoked charges that foreign donors are buying political influence.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Obama Acknowledges Scars of America’s Shadow War in Laos
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines at the Asean Summit in Vientiane, Laos, on Tuesday.
item.description: President Obama did not formally apologize for the bombs that the United States had dropped on the country but said that it would raise its aid to Laos.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Sinosphere: Shariah With Chinese Characteristics: A Scholar Looks at the Muslim Hui
item.media:description: Relatives riding in a truck with the body of an elderly Hui woman at a funeral in Linxia, a base for Islam in northwestern China.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Matthew S. Erie’s findings about the Hui ethnic group confound many preconceptions about Shariah, Chinese law and the rigidity of the Communist state.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: A Day of Bloodshed in Kabul: Attacks at Defense Ministry and Aid Compound
item.media:description: A man cleaned broken glass on Tuesday at the offices of a humanitarian group after an 11-hour standoff with gunmen in Kabul, Afghanistan.
item.description: After a double bombing that killed dozens in the area of the Defense Ministry, six people were wounded in an explosion at a humanitarian aid group’s compound.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL, ZAHRA NADER and FAHIM ABED

item.title: How Laos Tries to Balance Its Powerful Neighbors
item.media:description: Patrolling at the site of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations gathering in Vientiane, Laos. President Obama will be among those in attendance.
item.description: As the country hosts a meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, a university lecturer discusses its interactions with China, Vietnam and Thailand.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: What in the World: The Dog That’s Stealing Asians’ Hearts
item.media:description: Enjoying some poodle time in Beijing. Of the 950,000 dogs in Beijing last year, more than 13 percent, or about 125,000, were brown toy poodles, according to the Beijing Kennel Club.
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.description: The brown toy poodle has become has become a coveted pet in China, Taiwan and Japan.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: What in the World: In the Land of the Robot, Androids Are on the March
item.description: A handful of androids now greet visitors at a shopping mall and entertain on television. The company that made them plans to add them by the thousands.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Australia Needs the United States to Keep China in Check
item.description: Australia’s relations with China will be influenced significantly by how America conducts itself in the region.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FULLILOVE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Hero’s Burial for a Long-Dead Dictator
item.description: The Philippines’ new president wants to move Ferdinand Marcos’s body to a cemetery for heroes. It’s an affront to our history.
item.dc:creator: MIGUEL SYJUCO
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Nicolas Sarkozy Is Back, but France Has Changed
item.description: Does his country really want a divisive arsonist fighting its fires?
item.dc:creator: SYLVIE KAUFFMANN

item.title: How Russia Often Benefits When Julian Assange Reveals the West’s Secrets
item.media:description: Julian Assange looking out from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in February. Having lived there for four years, he is increasingly isolated.
item.description: American officials say Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks probably have no direct ties to Russian intelligence services. But the agendas of WikiLeaks and the Kremlin have often dovetailed.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER, STEVEN ERLANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Readers React: Seeing Orange: What Caught Commenters’ Eyes About a Small Syrian Boy in a Big Chair
item.media:description: Omran Daqneesh, 5, was rescued after an airstrike in the Syrian city of Aleppo.
item.description: Our Photo Editors’ Notebook on what made the image of Omran Daqneesh stand out inspired many readers to share their thoughts.
item.dc:creator: INSIDER STAFF
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
